summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Alison J. Nathan opposing Ghislaine Maxwell's defense request to adjourn her July 12, 2021 trial date. The government argues the defense has sufficient time to prepare for the superseding indictment (S2 Indictment), which focuses on four victims, and that delay would harm the victims. It also requests that if an adjournment is granted, the trial be rescheduled for March 2022 to ensure continuity of prosecution counsel.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (20 Cr. 330) facing charges including Mann Act violations; the defense is requesting an adjournment of her trial.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case to whom this government response letter is addressed.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York who signed and submitted this letter.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier whose crimes are the subject of the broader investigation; the discovery in the case includes materials from electronic devices seized from him.

persons.name: Minor Victim-2
persons.context: One of the victims referenced in the S2 Indictment; she opposes adjournment, has experienced stress, and plans to testify at the scheduled trial.

persons.name: Minor Victim-3
persons.context: One of the victims referenced in the S2 Indictment; she expressed significant stress and a strong desire for the trial to proceed as scheduled.

persons.name: Minor Victim-4
persons.context: A minor victim whose allegations are newly included in the S2 Indictment; the government provided the defense with a list of key documents relevant to her.

connections.description: Maxwell is charged in connection with crimes involving Jeffrey Epstein; the government's investigation and discovery materials pertain to both.
Minor Victim-2 is a victim referenced in the indictment who plans to testify against Maxwell at trial.
Minor Victim-3 is a victim referenced in the indictment who opposes adjournment and wishes to testify.
Minor Victim-4 is a new victim whose allegations are part of the superseding indictment (S2 Indictment).
Strauss, as U.S. Attorney, is leading the prosecution against defendant Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Return of S2 Superseding Indictment
events.description: A superseding indictment (S2 Indictment) was returned, adding new charges and allegations regarding Minor Victim-4.

events.title: Severance of Perjury Counts
events.description: The court issued an opinion and order severing the perjury counts from the upcoming trial.

events.title: Scheduled Trial Date
events.description: The trial on the non-perjury counts (Mann Act counts and new S2 charges) is scheduled to begin.

events.title: Major Discovery Production
events.description: The government produced approximately 1.2 million documents (2.2 million pages) from electronic devices seized from Jeffrey Epstein.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The government opposes adjourning Ghislaine Maxwell's July 12, 2021 trial, arguing the defense has had over three months since the March 29 superseding indictment to prepare.
The trial will focus primarily on the experiences of four victims referenced in the S2 Indictment, with the perjury counts having been severed.
Multiple victims, specifically Minor Victim-2 and Minor Victim-3, oppose any delay of the trial due to the significant stress they are experiencing.
The government states that the largest discovery production (1.2 million documents) came from Jeffrey Epstein's electronic devices and was produced in November 2020.

If the court grants an adjournment, the government requests the trial be rescheduled for March 2022 to ensure continuity of prosecution counsel who have pre-existing trial commitments in late 2021 and early 2022.
